entry.summary: ...STORM WILL BRING HEAVY SNOW TO THE HIGHWAYS... .A surface low will bring a strong front into the Panhandle late tonight through Monday. Snow will begin to fall along the highways early

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 24 at 2:34PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Through Tonight... Snow may continue over the South Slopes of the Alaska Range tapering off tonight. Snow could be heavy at times with brief low visibility. Snow amounts of 1 to 4 inches are expected through tonight over the Parks and Richardson Highways, with higher amounts above the highway level.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp; Southern Denali Borough

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 24 at 12:18PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Moderate Snowfall Through Sunday Evening... Snow will continue with light to moderate snowfall rates continuing, along with breezy winds at times which may limit visibility. Several inches of accumulation is possible. Snow should lighten and come to an end overnight into Monday morning.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 25 at 6:48AM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...LOCALLY DENSE FOG THIS MORNING... An area of locally dense fog is developing as winds move off the Potomac River this morning, with visibilities dropping as low as half a mile in spots. Dense fog is hazardous if driving at high speeds. Be prepared for rapidly changing visibility. Slow down and increase following distancee.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 24 at 1:42PM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...THREAT OF RIVER FLOODING MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY FOR THE SKOKOMISH RIVER IN MASON COUNTY... A frontal system passing through western Washington will bring rainfall amounts of 1 to 4 inches over portions of the Olympics. This amount of rainfall would result in the Skokomish River rising throughout the day Monday before cresting at or above flood stage
